bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, September 20, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes Cooke's participation in the yellow fever experiments and thinks he deserves recognition.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, September 20, 1940
div1.opener:
September 20, 1940
Dr. R. C. Hutchison
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Hutch:
div1.p:
Doctor Robert P. Cooke may be addressed at the Lexington-Rockbridge
Health Department, Lexington, Virginia.

You will remember from my memorandum, some confidential dope about Dr.
Cooke's less happy connection with yellow fever in Havana before Reed's work.
You will remember that he made up for this by bravely offering himself to Reed
to accept the experiments in the Infected Clothing Building. Although it turned
out that clothing soiled with the blood and excreta of patients who had had or
actually died of yellow fever could not pass on the disease, nevertheless, that
was the feeling at the time, and therefore it could probably be said that Dr.
Cook directly volunteered to face death. As it happens, he had merely a rather
trying psychological experience, and of course did not develop yellow fever. I
understand that he later revused or failed to volunteer for the actual mosquito
bites. For these reasons, he has lived very quietly, written nothing on his
experiences and gotten absolutely no publicity. It seems to me that since he
is the only medical man surviving who actually participated in the experiments,
that he deserves some recognition at this late date, although probably not as
much as Moran, Kissinger and others who actually developed yellow fever.
Please note my letter to Jordan about Moran.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
